item.title: Limits and continuity
item.description: Introduction Continuity Limits forms Theorems Conclusions Introduction Continuity If $f(x)$ is defined and continuous in the limit segment we want to calculate, than we can proceed. Put the limit value inside function and see if the result is an L $\in \mathbb{R}$. A function is continue in a point if the limit from left and right gives the same value in $\mathbb{R}$. That is: $$\lim_{x\to\ x_{0}^-} f(x) = L = \lim_{x\to\ x_{0}^+} f(x)$$ A function is continue in a range (or the full $\mathbb{R}$) if it’s continue in all the range’s points.
